titlestmt.titleproper: Morris C. McEldowney Military Service in East Asia Photograph Album, 1954-1955 RL.10981
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Katrina Martin

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-07-29 19:42:51 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Morris C. McEldowney Military Service in Korea and Japan photograph album
did.abstract: A hand-made photograph album by US Army Chaplain Morris C. McEldowney, dated 1954-1955. The album contains 190 photographs laid down on 172 stiff cardboard sheets, 7.5 x 4 inches, plus 6 small Japanese color woodblock views laid down on three more pages. The candid snapshots, with handwritten captions, are primarily of Seoul, Korea, the 8th Army military base, and the surrounding area. It also contains photograhs of Pusa, Korea, Tokyo, and Sendai, Japan.
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Morris C. McEldowney Military Service in East Asia Photo Album was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in December, 2014.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: A hand-made album of 190 photographs laid down on 172 stiff cardboard sheets, 7.5 x 4 inches, plus 6 small Japanese color woodblock views laid down on three more pages. Most of the black-and-white gelatin silver photographs measure 4.5 x 3.5 inches and are candid snapshots of the local people, shrines, public buildings, and marketplaces in and around Seoul. Some of the photographs are non-standard sizes, having been cut and cropped by McEldowney. McEldowney also carefully recorded notes in ink on what he was seeing, providing both historical and personal commentary in the margins of most of the pictures.

Twenty-four photographs are views of sites in Sendai and Tokyo, the rest are of Korea, and the 8th Army compound (Yongsan Garrison) in Seoul. He documented the refugee housing in Seoul, a barber shop set up inside a cave near the Thousand Steps, the Capitol Building constructed by the Japanese, the Korean royal palace (Gyeongbokgung), a white buddha statue located in a rock quarry, the Tomb of the Kings, women doing laundry in the river, and many street scenes.

The photographer captured pictures of U.S. Ambassador to Korea Ellis O. Briggs and his daughter Lucy, and his successor, William S. B. Lacy.Several of the chaplains stationed in Korea at this time also appear in the photographs, including Lewis Durden, Bernie Fenton, and John Woods. There are photographs of the opening ceremonies for the 8th Army Chaplain's Leadership School and Retreat, the DMZ, two Korean sisters who worked as secretaries and interpreters for the army, a YMCA school, and a local Boy Scout troop.
Titles of pages are provided by creator. Notes provided are verbatim transcripts of handwritten captions provided by creator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Morris C. McEldowney Military Service in East Asia Photograph Album, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Morris C. McEldowney (1905-1986) served 17 years as a Chaplain in the US Army, and retired from regular service in 1959. He saw three tours of duty in Europe and one in the Far East.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48-hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by: Katrina Martin, Alice Poffinberger, December, 2014
Accessions described in this finding aid: 2014-0198

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains 190 photographs on 172 sheets.

did.unittitle: 1: Panorama of Seoul Korea from the Namsan 1000 steps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In contrast to all the natural beauty, see what man has done to nature. Louie and I stop for a photo overlooking the city shown in panorama.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part of the wall surrounding the old city. Note: Lady at left in long waisted velvet traditional skirt.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Showing mountains in background

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Located in the national forest near ancient city wall built in 1398.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Near the Thousand Steps. The barber probably lives in the cave.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note John Good on wall - center of picture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wall was built in 1400s sometime

did.unittitle: 9: The Thousand Steps, Namsan Mountain, Seoul Korea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Overlooking city, Picture reverse: taken from the lower square

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Looking toward the top of Namsan Mountain. The steep cliffs of the mountain formed part of the ancient city wall--is now a national park.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sun through a gate in Kyong Bok palace. Capitol building was built by the Japanese and is unused by the present government out of President Rhee's extreme hatred of Japanese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A closer view from another gate in the palace grounds. Kyong Bok palace was built in 1395 and restored in 1865. It's the home of Korean kings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is an Oriental God--an idol, and the priest and acolyte are conducting ritual. It's located N/W of Seoul in a rock quarry some 15 miles from HQ. Although it was mid-afternoon--

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A cold wind was blowing. The 2 Buddhists finished their liturgy and went to their monastery on the rock ledge to R of picture. Picture was taken on icy surface of a stream. Note: liturgical vessels on altar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Surprising architecture is quite typically Korean but its location and size suggest a gasoline fueling station.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A memorial built in 1902 in memory of King Kojong's ascension. It's a little gem located in a busy street intersection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Royal library at Kyong Bok Palace built in 1867 by the Emperor Kojong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Courtyard in front of the palace buildings-- once a garden but rather unkempt at present.

did.unittitle: 19: Kozie and Koko, the two Miss Ko sisters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They have very unpronounceable Korean names so the GIs in the office have called them Kozie (R ) and Koko (L). Kozie is our secretary and interpreter leaving in Aug for Shenandoah College Va.

did.unittitle: 20: Kozie and Koko at the tombs of the Kings last Sunday

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Can you see any resemblance in features between Koreans of yesterday and today.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 13 story pagoda is the largest in Korea. Site commemorates a temple built in 1466.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pavilion with pagoda seen through to the rear.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Royal Banquet Hall built in 1412 by Tai Jong at the Kyong Bok Palace behind the capitol building. Damaged during Communist invasion and restored in 1954.

did.unittitle: 24: Kun Chun Moon palace gate at Kyong Bok.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Built in 1395 and restored in 1865. Stairs lead from either side to the guard tower which commands a view of surrounding terrain as well as palace grounds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: dates from 15th century. Located at one of Seoul's busy downtown traffic circles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: located on an island in a lagoon at Kyung Bok palace. Built in 1867. Bridge restored in 1953.

did.unittitle: 27: Han River Bridge, Seoul Korea, Mar 1955

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ann - It was at this point that thousands of Koreans died during the recent war. The Han river lies between Seoul and North K. and safety in the South. Some idiot blew the center span of this bridge 24 hours early and people drowned like rats.

did.unittitle: 28: Korean Memorial of Han River near Seoul

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: River and mountains in the background looking toward Seoul bay and the river. I really do not know what the monument commemorates but one suggestion appears obverse.

did.unittitle: 29: Tombs of Kings near Seoul - Kozie and Koko

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Monument is to represent the king and the second figure is his chief steward or something. Animals are horses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The flat rock is a table where the family came for ceremonial meal with the departed spirit of dead king. The pagoda type object to L of table is where a light is kept burning.

did.unittitle: 31: Banquet Hall of the Korean Kings in Seoul

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Located in Kyung Bok Palace. Architecture is classical period built in 1412.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: in a lily-flecked lagoon in the palace grounds. Kyong Bok Seoul.

did.unittitle: 33: Stone Lions - Kyung Bok Palace, Seoul

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 of 16 original lions flanking the Forbidden bridge, guarding the palace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In ancient days an overnight journey from Seoul to the East. Located on hills in a quiet valley, nine tombs are preserved marking the burial palace of Korea's rulers. Now preserved as national park.

did.unittitle: 35: From Guard Tower overlooking Kyung Bok Palace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: L: Forbidden Bridge, R: Audience Hall with stone lions adorning entrance, built 1394.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Located adjacent to Chang Duck palace grounds - favorite picnic area.

did.unittitle: 37: Street Scene Seoul, Note South Gate in background

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken Sunday afternoon in Dec 54.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note: East meets West in men's garb. Note: Sign in English reading "Paint Shop" and below same legend in Korean or Chinese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laborer wearing loaded "A" Frame. All students in Korea wear the student uniform -- lad behind the laborer. Left- Completely Western garb of hatless youth.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Several families share a common inner court surrounded by stone wall and single entrance.

did.unittitle: 44: Capitol Building Seoul, and the Gate to the Capitol Grounds

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Building is unused today because built by Japanese and a bitter reminder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Open stall market

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Street vendors, open stall market costume. Chaplain Durden

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This market extends for 2 city blocks and is jammed with miscellaneous items as you see here and crowds of people.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Containers are made of rice straw. The tent is US Army surplus.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Many of the refugees from beyond the DMZ live in cramped temporary shelters in Seoul. City population is swollen beyond capacity. Some live even in caves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sanitation under normal conditions just doesn't exist and during the rainy season becomes a swampy matrix of germs and infection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note: 1) No hands - woman in foreground. 2) Student uniform - All children in school are required to wear this uniform - the little girl left of center. 3) Slacks 4)Hair styling 5) Open shop.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This picture is almost American or European. It might be almost any American city. Only one thing in picture marking the scene as oriental and that is the hand cart in the center of the picture.

did.unittitle: 53: Kemchee Market, Yong Dong Do, Korea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bales of Chinese cabbage in background. Other items = red pepper, garlic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Yes, the man in white is doing exactly what he appears to be doing. And Korea turns its head in unconcern.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An especially good study of Korean types. Papa San with his placid gestures. Young matron - sweet faced. A student in uniform. And the child at the bottom of the picture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: I tried to catch John beside Miss Korea at the bus stop by my shutter jammed and a second later, he had a telephone pole between them.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These rice straw mats serve as floor coverings and mattresses. Rather a typical item of oriental home economy-- not strictly Korean since use and manufacture were introduced by the Japanese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Looking toward Nam San Mountain. Ch. W with camera in center of street.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Located just at the top of the thousand steps, this Pentecostal group has indulged the customary emotional excesses even to an attempt to convert Chaplain Durden.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the EDE-WA shoes, bloused trousers, the white, white robe, hat, beard, and cane. Taken on road to the 1000 steps. Nam Sam or South Mountain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As we came along he had just taken mail from the street pillar mail box. J.W. has his attention as I snapped any picture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He speaks a little English. He wears a wrist watch. He sees much and knows much as is much interested in the world. He loves his barren hills and scrub pines and is willing and capable of fighting.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wears glasses and a "Papa San" hat @ 4000 Hwan. His smile hides a shyness and suspicion of cameras and everything western. He is conservative, suspicious, resists change. He loves the old order, the ancient ways and nurses ancient hatreds including Japan.

did.unittitle: 67: Draft Oxen, Kemchee Market, Yong dong Do Korea
68: Mongolian Horse, Kemchee Market, Yong Dong Do, Korea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Preparation of the soil for planting rice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two aces visit the Kings. If your wish is a clever title. Taken Memorial Da afternoon 1955.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sun 14 Nov 54

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: View toward K-16 Seoul City Airport

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two little girls too busy to watch the camera. The game is marbles. Place - the busy MSR* playground sidewalk or what passes as a walk -- packed clay. Seoul *Main Supply Route

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Faces of the elderly are very impressive. A mood of serenity and mental alertness is characteristic. There is a certainty and a mark of quality about this old gentleman in spite of clothing. Note padded - or quilted pants.

did.unittitle: 75: Korean with "A" frame loaded with dustless mops

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken on MSR. Note curbing and temporary fence - evidence of war damage. MSR - Main Supply Route

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In USA they would be on Grayce's front lawn with petunias. In Korea kimchee is anything but a petunia. Note dress = 1) Korean low, pointed shoes 2) GI jacket, hat 3) Also, beard.

did.unittitle: 77: Laundry in Han River near K-16 Airstrip
78: Korean laborer with "A" frame Yong Dong Do

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Little girl was camera shy -- refused to pose and ducked her head as I snapped. K-16 and mountains in background. Nov 54

did.unittitle: 80: Sunday afternoon on Han River near Seoul

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Picture shows Korean baby sling. Men never carry babies. Women never wear "A" frame.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This might serve as a front piece to your collection of snaps. Goodness knows you have seen this number often. Through this building -- it's really quite large, goes all the thousands of letters and packages. It's the gateway to my daily visit home.

did.unittitle: 82: Entrance to Eighth Army Chaplain's Office. Big Durden Little Tree: Chaplain Lewis Durden, roommate at A-37
83: Eighth Army Compound from chopper pad

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Corner of my house shows at lower left. Quonset below house is mess hall. Office is bldg. in center and to right of cen. racing field.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Life-size manger scene

did.unittitle: 85: Taken in front of Army Chaplain office

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Papa San - Jeep driver of No. 35. Mamma San, our housekeeper. Our Mamma San is one to right

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mother and baby - showing baby sling and method of carrying cargo on head. Note bandage on baby's ear. Korean dirt farmer in traditional whites. Note open sewer on left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Street up to latrine down to office. My room and entrance

did.unittitle: 88: Quarters North Post, Yongsan Seoul, Eighth Army HQ
89: Looking toward North Post from 8th Army Chaplain's office
90: View from office, Eighth Army Chaplain

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chapel, parade ground, athletic field. Chaplain Bernie Fenton.

did.unittitle: 91: Headquarters Chapel 8 Army Forward, Seoul Korea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Headquarters Chapel Eighth Army Forward

did.unittitle: 93: Headquarters Chapel Eighth Army, Yongsan Seoul Korea,
94: Eighth Army HQ Chapel, Yongsan, Seoul Korea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note: size of windows. My room is rear corner of left wing, 2nd floor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Picture taken from mountainside. From left- right Quonset - billets, Chapel - adjoining kitchen and dining room. Right - office and billets for HQ det.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: View from the old city wall overlooking the Han River and K-16.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Replica of gate appears on 100 hwan notes. Located on road to Musan-ni.

did.unittitle: 100: Everybody takes pictures of everybody in Korea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lt Brennan at right, escort for Dr. Poling.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pictures snapped at Eighth Army heliport Fri 24 Dec. Showing John Woods arriving from the 1st marine division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pictures taken Thanksgiving afternoon on a walk along the MSR. Women working with the paving gang refused to pose so John grabbed one of the shovels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mary Gryader, administrative assistant (center) with Chaplain Woods and Fay Persons, a friend. The day she arrived at K-14.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Our cottage in the woods. My room is facing road on the rear. Concrete porch faces the Han river and a chain of mountains, now has white lawn chairs and table.

did.unittitle: 105: Opening Ceremonies Eighth Army Chaplain Leadership School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gen Beach giving address, Chaplain Woods invocation

did.unittitle: 106: Opening Ceremonies Chaplain Leadership School and Retreat Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken during the singing of "America."

did.unittitle: 107: Retreat Center view from hills. Opening Ceremony
108: Retreat Center: taken from the hills above the compound

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: EV Robie was with me.

did.unittitle: 109: Ambassador Briggs, his daughter Lucy, and the mayor of Seoul in hospital ward at the time of dedication
110: Lucy with one of the orphan babies in the hospital

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This hospital really is Lucy Briggs' project. Guess she has turned everybody upside down to get the building and the equipment. Baby really looks sick.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is the residence of Ambassador Briggs in American Embassy Compound. Picture was taken on 22 Feb. at time of my visit in connection with the dedication of the Children's Hospital.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: American flag on foreign soil -- flying above the snow-covered parade ground in the Eighth Army (forward) Headquarters. Picture was taken from the Eighth Army HQ Chapel, looking toward HQ building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Review in honor of Ambassador Lacey, recently appointed American Ambassador to Korea. Honor guard and color guard. Han San mountain in background.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Guard reviewed by Lt. Gen Ferrenbaugh, General Disney, Ambassador Lacey, Second row 8 A G staff. In background - 8 Army Chapel, theatre, library.

did.unittitle: 115: Dr. Daniel Poling with Mrs. Lutz, missionary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photo = at the Presbyterian mission in Seoul. Dr. Ed Adams, Mr. Lutz, Mrs. Lutz, Dr. Poling. Entrance to Adams residence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plane is the Batan and field is K-16. Miss Sitler and Chaplain Woods join the group.

did.unittitle: 118: Dr. Poling precedes the General into the plane

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note: 4 stars on star. Army commanders plane. Ready to leave -- some officer changed his mind at the last minute.

did.unittitle: 119: John Woods clowning with an "A" frame

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note: Expressions on faces of Koreans. Orientals have a sense of humor and know a good joke when they see it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ambassador and Mrs. Briggs are the two on the inside of foursome. Sue Adams at the L of picture and Ned Adams R. Adams I have mentioned frequently as Deans of Presbyterians here.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Y" runs school for some 1200 children in these squad tent classrooms. Children here are waifs picked up from the streets by Boy Scouts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Youngster in the baby ward , an orphan. This is the hospital that Lucy Briggs was interested in.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lanterns have the "Y" triangle symbol and burn candles. Two of the street waifs rescued by the Scouts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Scout hut in background where the rescued children live until they can be placed in houses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At Retreat Center Chapel. This is the bride who kept the groom waiting 3 hours.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This picture was taken during our walk on Thanksgiving Day. We met the Chaplain (R ) of the G? regiment and stopped for pictures. Background, 8th Army compound.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Picture taken during one of our Saturday jaunts on the heights overlooking the Chaplain School and the Han River Valley.

did.unittitle: 129: Christmas Party at the Retreat Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Orphans, Miss Ko, Chaplain, Civ. Secretary, and Johnson our clerk as Santa.

did.unittitle: 130: Orphans, Christmas Party at Retreat House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken shortly after I had retrieved my Samoca from residence of Sigmund Rhee where I had left it inadvertently during my visit with Dr. Blake.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At left: Hong Soon Il (Jeep 35), kyung Ae Ko (Secretary), Lee Heung Kuk (House boy), Yang Yong Suk (Jeep 36). Right: Mama san, her son. I don't even know their Korean names.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left: Yongsan area near 8th Army compound. Right: downtown Seoul. Both pictures show women balancing objects on their heads.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Some of the Easter sunrise service crowd going by the Thousand Steps from the top of Han San.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hardly visible is the Easter cross down left center. Crowd is breaking up and departing from the mountain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Right to left: Durden (Dovie), McCracken (Mac), McE (me), Woods (John), Blank (don't know). Vice Dres. Of Korea (State national (??) guard in rear.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Right to left: US flag, UN flag, Korean, Christian

did.unittitle: 137: Ko sisters at Easter Sunrise Service

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Koko (L), Kozie (R )

did.unittitle: 139: Memorial Day Ceremonies at 8A FWD memorial to Korean War US soldiers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Monument is located at North Gate Main Post. At R. is General Ferrenbaugh

did.unittitle: 140: Memorial Day at Korean Soldier Monument on Han River

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Front center: Ferrenbaugh, Front R facing monument: Ambassador Lacey. 3rd row - civilian is Karl Strum, US charge d'affairs. Next: Col. Ed Wilson, our roommate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Part of Pusan -- area nearest Japan-- has the best shipping facilities in Korea. (F???) was the site of America's last-ditch stand before our invasion at Incheon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Another view from same location on a hill above the PX.

did.unittitle: 143: North: Sign reads "Southern limit demilitarized zone: Do not enter"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken on Wednesday during my visit as escort for Ken Fristoe at OP site overlooking DMZ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Waiting for my plane on Friday. Herschel Ineeder and I wandered to beach near K-9. Water here is the Yellow Sea and direction is toward the China Coast.

did.unittitle: 145: L to R; Ch. Schlieser, 2 officers (one is Reg. Commander), Ch. Fristoe, Ch. Redford

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Party stands on height overlooking the Imjin River and the DMZ as shown on reverse.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Freedom Bridge lies between the 2 ink dots on river bank. Below at base of mountain is US civil camp and a dust spangled road leading from river. Korean civilians are not permitted N of Imjin.

did.unittitle: 147: Looking North into the Commie Territory from US observation post

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note line of pen marks on photo. Hardly visible above each dot is a white panel marker indicating Southern boundary or DMZ 3 miles beyond are red flags.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Preparation of paddy for the planting of rice. This is just plain mud. Can you imagine conducting a war through this kind of terrain? No place for fox holes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is taken from the chaplain's office in Camp Shimmelpfennig. 1st Cav Div HQ. The rotary in front of N building was simply loaded with color. Flowers of all shapes and hues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This picture was taken from near the same spot as the one on reverse. This is the 1st Cav Div chapel in Shim. Road and walk in foreground lead to the chaplain's office.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Showing front entrance, maids quarters to R and to R beyond the separate maids quarters, the garage. Foreground: board fence which encloses compound. Maid Ishii San is (???), has a husband - a tailor- and 4 children. All live in 3 rooms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: French doors slide open. At L is a fish pond with fish. Not in picture at L is a fence and the electric power relay station.

did.unittitle: 153: House - from terrace looking toward street

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Street car passing in distance. Direction is toward town of Sendu -- hospital, camp Sendai, Camp Shim.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Living room. Ch. Cooper in chair. Mirror over fireplace reflects the street forest of beams to my rear which is the view from living room and living room French doors. Curtains are installed-- maybe cerise in color -- covering doors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is the Japanese counterpart to the church or cathedral. Note the variety of gables in this picture and the one on back.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Some kind of ceremony was taking place inside this building but I didn't try to go in. The temple was surrounded by flowers and gardens and fountains.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tokyo has no sky scrapers although it's the 3rd largest city in the world. Reason: the frequent earthquakes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: En route to my office. Office bldg. at L of picture with the smaller building housing latrine facilities. Am facing toward Faith Hall and S Post.

did.unittitle: 161: Monument in Hibiya Park, Palace Grounds Tokyo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Horse is particularly good -- mounted warrior in armor. Picture at left was taken against Sun - I tried for silhouette.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This was one of several entrances. Most of them were closed. This is the only one which seemed to be in use.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This bell is an exact replica of the liberty bell in Philadelphia. It stands on a knoll in the park overlooking the tennis courts. It is nearly hidden and I discovered it by accident.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Some severe looking person whose identity I could not learn, and whose features were so weathered and black even my camera failed to record. Probably an emperor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is one of the entrances to the palace.

did.unittitle: 166: Plaza in font of Imperial Palace in Tokyo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There were hundreds of tourists, particularly school children, surrounding this plaza.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rather an unusual picture. Should have had more light. The fountain was an attractive spot right in the center of Hibya Park in downtown Tokyo.

did.unittitle: 168: Lion at entrance of Shinto Shrine, Tokyo. Monument near the Imperial Palace, Tokyo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is not far from the famed Imperial Hotel and adjacent to the Imperial Palace. It has beauty as you can see from this lagoon and fountain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: I was able to crowd a great deal into this picture. I fact there is much more in his picture than there is in the park. I was quite mystified when the picture came from the developer until I discovered that it is a double exposure.

did.unittitle: 171: Stone turtle at base of pillar
172: Stone turtle at base of monument
